trigger: The suppression of T cell function and NF ( kappa ) B expression by serine protease inhibitors is blocked by N - acetylcysteine .
Direct evidence that N - acetylcysteine ( NAC ) enhances the immune response of peripheral blood T cells at the level of NF ( kappa ) B is presented .
In addition , NAC blocks the suppression of T cell mitogenesis and cytokine production by protease inhibitors such as N - tosylphenylalanine chloromethyl ketone ( TPCK ) .

The proliferative responses of purified <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + or CD8+ T cells are suppressed more strongly by TPCK when anti-CD28 rather than the phorbol ester PMA is used as the mitogenic coactivator .

Cytokine ( <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> INF-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) production is inhibited 95-100 % by concentrations of TPCK that totally suppress the mitogenesis of <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + or CD8+ cells .

Using electrophoretic mobility shift assays , we find that TPCK virtually abolishes ( to less than 1 % ) the levels of NF ( kappa ) B ( but not <extra_id_0> Oct-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) found in nuclear and whole cell extracts of activated T cells .
Strikingly , the immunosuppressive effects of TPCK are blocked when T cells are pretreated for 15 min with 5 mM NAC .
NAC not only blocks the effect of TPCK but enhances mitogenesis and cytokine production ( > 2.5-fold in some cases ) upon activation of unsuppressed T cells .
Our data support the notion that NF ( kappa ) B and I ( kappa ) B proteases play obligate roles in T cell activation and mitogenesis , roles that are enhanced significantly by NAC .
